</p><p>The Daleks were created by writer <a href="/wiki/Terry_Nation" title="Terry Nation">Terry Nation</a> (who intended them to be an <a href="/wiki/Allegory" title="Allegory">allegory</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nazism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nazism (page does not exist)">Nazis</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[102]</a></sup> and BBC designer <a href="/wiki/Raymond_Cusick" title="Raymond Cusick">Raymond Cusick</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-cusick_108-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cusick-108">[103]</a></sup> The Daleks' début in the programme's second serial, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daleks" title="The Daleks">The Daleks</a></i> (1963–64), made both the Daleks and  <i>Doctor Who</i> very popular. A Dalek appeared on a postage stamp celebrating British popular culture in 1999, photographed by <a href="/wiki/Antony_Armstrong-Jones,_1st_Earl_of_Snowdon" title="Antony Armstrong-Jones, 1st Earl of Snowdon">Lord Snowdon</a>. In the new series, Daleks come in a range of colours; the colour of a Dalek denotes its role within the species.
</p><p>In the 2012 episode "Asylum of the Daleks", every generation of the Dalek species made an appearance.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Cybermen">Cybermen</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Cybermen were originally a wholly organic species of humanoids originating on Earth's <a href="/wiki/Counter-Earth" title="Counter-Earth">twin planet</a> Mondas that began to implant more and more artificial parts into their bodies. This led to the race becoming coldly logical and calculating <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cyborg&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cyborg (page does not exist)">cyborgs</a>, with emotions usually only shown when naked aggression was called for. With the demise of Mondas, they acquired Telos as their new home planet. They continue to be a recurring 'monster' within the <i>Doctor Who</i> franchise.
</p><p>The 2006 series introduced a totally new variation of Cybermen. These Cybus Cybermen were created in a <a href="/wiki/Parallel_universe_(fiction)" title="Parallel universe (fiction)">parallel universe</a> by the mad inventor John Lumic; he was attempting to preserve the life of a human by transplanting their brains into powerful metal bodies, sending them orders using a mobile phone network and inhibiting their emotions with an electronic chip. In November 2012, <a href="/wiki/Neil_Gaiman" title="Neil Gaiman">Neil Gaiman</a> confirmed that the Cybermen would feature in an upcoming series 7 episode he has written.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[105]</a></sup> This episode, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Nightmare_in_Silver&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nightmare in Silver (page does not exist)">Nightmare in Silver</a>", was broadcast in 2013.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Master">The Master</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The Master is the Doctor's <a href="/wiki/Archenemy" title="Archenemy">archenemy</a>, a renegade <a href="/wiki/Time_Lord" title="Time Lord">Time Lord</a> who desires to rule the universe. Conceived as "<a href="/wiki/Professor_Moriarty" title="Professor Moriarty">Professor Moriarty</a> to the Doctor's <a href="/wiki/Sherlock_Holmes" title="Sherlock Holmes">Sherlock Holmes</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[106]</a></sup> the character first appeared in 1971. As with the Doctor, the role has been portrayed by several actors, since the Master is a Time Lord as well and able to regenerate; the first of these actors was <a href="/wiki/Roger_Delgado" title="Roger Delgado">Roger Delgado</a>, who continued in the role until his death in 1973. The Master was briefly played by <a href="/wiki/Peter_Pratt" title="Peter Pratt">Peter Pratt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_Beevers" title="Geoffrey Beevers">Geoffrey Beevers</a> until <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Ainley" title="Anthony Ainley">Anthony Ainley</a> took over and continued to play the character until Doctor Who's hiatus in 1989. The Master returned in the 1996 television movie of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_(1996_film)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who (1996 film) (page does not exist)">Doctor Who</a></i>, and was played by American actor <a href="/wiki/Eric_Roberts" title="Eric Roberts">Eric Roberts</a>.
</p><p>The Master has appeared in the revived series, portrayed for one episode by <a href="/wiki/Derek_Jacobi" title="Derek Jacobi">Derek Jacobi</a> before the character regenerated, and otherwise <a href="/wiki/John_Simm" title="John Simm">John Simm</a> since then.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[107]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theme_music">Theme music</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Side_box&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Side box (page does not exist)">Template:Side box</a><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Main_other&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Main other (page does not exist)">Template:Main other</a>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who_theme_music" title="Doctor Who theme music">Doctor Who theme music</a> was one of the first <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic music</a> signature tunes for television, and after five decades remains one of the most easily recognised. It has been often called both memorable and frightening, priming the viewer for what was to follow. During the 1970s, the <i><a href="/wiki/Radio_Times" title="Radio Times">Radio Times</a></i>, the BBC's own <a href="/w/index.php?title=Listings_magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Listings magazine (page does not exist)">listings magazine</a>, announced that a child's mother said the theme music terrified her son. The <i>Radio Times</i> was apologetic, but the theme music remained.
</p><p>The original theme was composed by <a href="/wiki/Ron_Grainer" title="Ron Grainer">Ron Grainer</a> and realised by <a href="/wiki/Delia_Derbyshire" title="Delia Derbyshire">Delia Derbyshire</a> of the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radiophonic_Workshop" title="BBC Radiophonic Workshop">BBC Radiophonic Workshop</a>, with assistance from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dick_Mills&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dick Mills (page does not exist)">Dick Mills</a>. The various parts were built up using <a href="/wiki/Musique_concr%C3%A8te" title="Musique concrète">musique concrète</a> techniques, by creating <a href="/wiki/Tape_loop" title="Tape loop">tape loops</a> of an individually struck piano string and individual test <a href="/wiki/Oscillation" title="Oscillation">oscillators</a> and filters. The Derbyshire arrangement served, with minor edits, as the theme tune up to the end of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_serials#Season_17_.281979.E2.80.9380.29" title="List of Doctor Who serials">Season 17</a> (1979–80). It is widely regarded as a significant and innovative piece of electronic music, recorded well before the availability of commercial synthesisers or multitrack mixers. Each note was individually created by cutting, splicing, speeding up and slowing down segments of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Magnetic_tape_sound_recording&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Magnetic tape sound recording (page does not exist)">analogue tape</a> containing recordings of a single plucked string, <a href="/wiki/White_noise" title="White noise">white noise</a>, and the simple <a href="/wiki/Harmonic" title="Harmonic">harmonic</a> waveforms of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tone_generator&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tone generator (page does not exist)">test-tone oscillators</a>, intended for calibrating equipment and rooms, not creating music. New techniques were invented to allow <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mixing_(music)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mixing (music) (page does not exist)">mixing</a> of the music, as this was before the era of multitrack tape machines. On hearing the finished result, Grainer was amazed, and famously asked, "Did I write that?".
</p><p>A different arrangement was recorded by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Howell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Howell (page does not exist)">Peter Howell</a> for <a href="/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_serials#Season_18_.281980.E2.80.9381.29" title="List of Doctor Who serials">Season 18</a> (1980), which was in turn replaced by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominic_Glynn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominic Glynn (page does not exist)">Dominic Glynn</a>'s arrangement for the season-long serial <i><a href="/wiki/The_Trial_of_a_Time_Lord" title="The Trial of a Time Lord">The Trial of a Time Lord</a></i> in <a href="/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_serials#Season_23_.281986.29" title="List of Doctor Who serials">Season 23</a> (1986). <a href="/w/index.php?title=Keff_McCulloch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Keff McCulloch (page does not exist)">Keff McCulloch</a> provided the new arrangement for the <a href="/wiki/Seventh_Doctor" title="Seventh Doctor">Seventh Doctor</a>'s era which lasted from <a href="/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_serials#Season_24_.281987.29" title="List of Doctor Who serials">Season 24</a> (1987) until the series' suspension in 1989. American composer <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Debney&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Debney (page does not exist)">John Debney</a> created a new arrangement of <a href="/wiki/Ron_Grainer" title="Ron Grainer">Ron Grainer</a>'s original theme for <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who_(film)" title="Doctor Who (film)">Doctor Who</a></i> in 1996. For the return of the series in 2005, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Murray_Gold&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Murray Gold (page does not exist)">Murray Gold</a> provided a new arrangement which featured <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sampling_(music)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sampling (music) (page does not exist)">samples</a> from the 1963 original with further elements added; in the 2005 Christmas episode "<a href="/wiki/The_Christmas_Invasion" title="The Christmas Invasion">The Christmas Invasion</a>", Gold introduced a modified closing credits arrangement that was used up until the conclusion of the 2007 series.
</p><p>A new arrangement of the theme, once again by Gold, was introduced in the 2007 Christmas special episode, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Voyage_of_the_Damned_(Doctor_Who)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Voyage of the Damned (Doctor Who) (page does not exist)">Voyage of the Damned</a>"; Gold returned as composer for the 2010 season.<sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[108]</a></sup> He was responsible for a new version of the theme which was reported to have had a hostile reception from some viewers.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[109]</a></sup> In 2011, the theme tune charted at number 228 of radio station Classic FM's Hall of Fame, a survey of classical music tastes. A revised version of Gold's 2010 arrangement had its debut over the opening titles of the 2012 Christmas Special <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Snowmen&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Snowmen (page does not exist)">The Snowmen</a></i>, and a further revision of the arrangement was made for the 50th Anniversary special "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Day_of_the_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Day of the Doctor (page does not exist)">The Day of the Doctor</a>" in November 2013.
</p><p>Versions of the "Doctor Who Theme" have also been released as pop music over the years. In the early 1970s, Jon Pertwee, who had played the Third Doctor, recorded a version of the Doctor Who theme with spoken lyrics, titled, "Who Is the Doctor".<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[note 6]</a></sup> In 1978 a disco version of the theme was released in the UK, Denmark and Australia by the group Mankind, which reached number 24 in the UK charts. In 1988 the band The Justified Ancients of Mu Mu (later known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_KLF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The KLF (page does not exist)">The KLF</a>) released the single "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctorin%27_the_Tardis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctorin' the Tardis (page does not exist)">Doctorin' the Tardis</a>" under the name The Timelords, which reached No. 1 in the UK and No. 2 in Australia; this version incorporated several other songs, including "Rock and Roll Part 2" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gary_Glitter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gary Glitter (page does not exist)">Gary Glitter</a> (who recorded vocals for some of the CD-single remix versions of "Doctorin' the Tardis").<sup id="cite_ref-guardianmusic_116-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardianmusic-116">[110]</a></sup> Others who have covered or reinterpreted the theme include <a href="/wiki/Orbital_(band)" title="Orbital (band)">Orbital</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-guardianmusic_116-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardianmusic-116">[110]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pink_Floyd&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pink Floyd (page does not exist)">Pink Floyd</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-guardianmusic_116-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardianmusic-116">[110]</a></sup> the Australian string ensemble <a href="/w/index.php?title=FourPlay_Electric_String_Quartet&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="FourPlay Electric String Quartet (page does not exist)">Fourplay</a>, New Zealand punk band <a href="/wiki/Blam_Blam_Blam" title="Blam Blam Blam">Blam Blam Blam</a>, <a href="/wiki/The_Pogues" title="The Pogues">The Pogues</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thin_Lizzy" title="Thin Lizzy">Thin Lizzy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dub_Syndicate" title="Dub Syndicate">Dub Syndicate</a>, and the comedians <a href="/wiki/Bill_Bailey" title="Bill Bailey">Bill Bailey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mitch_Benn" title="Mitch Benn">Mitch Benn</a>, and it and obsessive fans were satirised on <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Chaser%27s_War_on_Everything&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Chaser's War on Everything (page does not exist)">The Chaser's War on Everything</a></i>. The theme tune has also appeared on many compilation CDs and has made its way into mobile phone ring tones. Fans have also produced and distributed their own remixes of the theme. In January 2011 the Mankind version was released as a <a href="/wiki/Music_download" title="Music download">digital download</a> on the album <i>Gallifrey And Beyond</i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Incidental_music">Incidental music</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Most of the innovative incidental music for <i>Doctor Who</i> has been specially commissioned from freelance composers, although in the early years some episodes also used <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royalty_free_music&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royalty free music (page does not exist)">stock music</a>, as well as occasional excerpts from original recordings or <a href="/wiki/Cover_version" title="Cover version">cover versions</a> of songs by popular music acts such as <a href="/wiki/The_Beatles" title="The Beatles">The Beatles</a> and <a href="/wiki/The_Beach_Boys" title="The Beach Boys">The Beach Boys</a>. Since its 2005 return, the series has featured occasional use of excerpts of pop music from the 1970s to the 2000s.
</p><p>The incidental music for the first <i>Doctor Who</i> adventure, <i>An Unearthly Child</i>, was written by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Norman_Kay_(composer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Norman Kay (composer) (page does not exist)">Norman Kay</a>. Many of the stories of the <a href="/wiki/William_Hartnell" title="William Hartnell">William Hartnell</a> period were scored by electronic music pioneer <a href="/wiki/Tristram_Cary" title="Tristram Cary">Tristram Cary</a>, whose <i>Doctor Who</i> credits include <i>The Daleks</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Marco_Polo_(Doctor_Who)" title="Marco Polo (Doctor Who)">Marco Polo</a></i>, <i>The Daleks' Master Plan</i>, <i>The Gunfighters</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Mutants" title="The Mutants">The Mutants</a></i>. Other composers in this early period included <a href="/wiki/Richard_Rodney_Bennett" title="Richard Rodney Bennett">Richard Rodney Bennett</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Carey_Blyton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Carey Blyton (page does not exist)">Carey Blyton</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Geoffrey_Burgon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Geoffrey Burgon (page does not exist)">Geoffrey Burgon</a>.
</p><p>The most frequent musical contributor during the first 15 years was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dudley_Simpson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dudley Simpson (page does not exist)">Dudley Simpson</a>, who is also well known for his theme and incidental music for <i><a href="/wiki/Blake%27s_7" title="Blake's 7">Blake's 7</a></i>, and for his haunting theme music and score for the original 1970s version of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Tomorrow_People" title="The Tomorrow People">The Tomorrow People</a></i>. Simpson's first <i>Doctor Who</i> score was <i><a href="/wiki/Planet_of_Giants" title="Planet of Giants">Planet of Giants</a></i> (1964) and he went on to write music for many adventures of the 1960s and 1970s, including most of the stories of the Jon Pertwee/Tom Baker periods, ending with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Horns_of_Nimon" title="The Horns of Nimon">The Horns of Nimon</a></i> (1979). He also made a <a href="/wiki/Cameo_appearance" title="Cameo appearance">cameo appearance</a> in <i>The Talons of Weng-Chiang</i> (as a <a href="/wiki/Music_hall" title="Music hall">Music hall</a> conductor).
</p><p>In 1980 starting with the serial <i><a href="/wiki/The_Leisure_Hive" title="The Leisure Hive">The Leisure Hive</a></i> the task of creating incidental music was assigned to the Radiophonic Workshop. <a href="/wiki/Paddy_Kingsland" title="Paddy Kingsland">Paddy Kingsland</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Peter_Howell&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Peter Howell (page does not exist)">Peter Howell</a> contributed many scores in this period and other contributors included <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roger_Limb&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roger Limb (page does not exist)">Roger Limb</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Malcolm_Clarke&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Malcolm Clarke (page does not exist)">Malcolm Clarke</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jonathan_Gibbs_(composer)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jonathan Gibbs (composer) (page does not exist)">Jonathan Gibbs</a>.
</p><p>The Radiophonic Workshop was dropped after 1986's <i><a href="/wiki/The_Trial_of_a_Time_Lord" title="The Trial of a Time Lord">The Trial of a Time Lord</a></i> series, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Keff_McCulloch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Keff McCulloch (page does not exist)">Keff McCulloch</a> took over as the series' main composer until the end of its run, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dominic_Glynn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dominic Glynn (page does not exist)">Dominic Glynn</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mark_Ayres&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mark Ayres (page does not exist)">Mark Ayres</a> also contributing scores.
</p><p>All the incidental music for the 2005 revived series has been composed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Murray_Gold&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Murray Gold (page does not exist)">Murray Gold</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ben_Foster_(orchestrator)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ben Foster (orchestrator) (page does not exist)">Ben Foster</a> and has been performed by the <a href="/wiki/BBC_National_Orchestra_of_Wales" title="BBC National Orchestra of Wales">BBC National Orchestra of Wales</a> from the 2005 Christmas episode "<a href="/wiki/The_Christmas_Invasion" title="The Christmas Invasion">The Christmas Invasion</a>" onwards. A concert featuring the orchestra performing music from the first two series took place on 19 November 2006 to raise money for Children in Need. David Tennant hosted the event, introducing the different sections of the concert. Murray Gold and <a href="/wiki/Russell_T_Davies" title="Russell T Davies">Russell T Davies</a> answered questions during the interval and <a href="/wiki/Dalek" title="Dalek">Daleks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cyberman" title="Cyberman">Cybermen</a> appeared whilst music from their stories was played. The concert aired on <a href="/wiki/BBC_Red_Button" title="BBC Red Button">BBCi</a> on Christmas Day 2006. A <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_Prom_(2008)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who Prom (2008) (page does not exist)">Doctor Who Prom</a> was celebrated on 27 July 2008 in the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Albert_Hall" title="Royal Albert Hall">Royal Albert Hall</a> as part of the annual <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC_Proms&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC Proms (page does not exist)">BBC Proms</a>. The BBC Philharmonic and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=London_Philharmonic_Choir&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="London Philharmonic Choir (page does not exist)">London Philharmonic Choir</a> performed Murray Gold's compositions for the series, conducted by Ben Foster, as well as a selection of classics based on the theme of space and time. The event was presented by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Freema_Agyeman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freema Agyeman (page does not exist)">Freema Agyeman</a> and guest-presented by various other stars of the show with numerous monsters participating in the proceedings. It also featured the specially filmed mini-episode "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Music_of_the_Spheres_(Doctor_Who)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Music of the Spheres (Doctor Who) (page does not exist)">Music of the Spheres</a>", written by Russell T Davies and starring David Tennant.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>Six soundtrack releases have been released since 2005. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_Original_Television_Soundtrack&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: Original Television Soundtrack (page does not exist)">first</a> featured tracks from the first two series,<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[112]</a></sup> the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_Original_Television_Soundtrack_-_Series_3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: Original Television Soundtrack - Series 3 (page does not exist)">second</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_Original_Television_Soundtrack_-_Series_4&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: Original Television Soundtrack - Series 4 (page does not exist)">third</a> featured music from the third and fourth series respectively. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_Original_Television_Soundtrack_-_Series_4:_The_Specials&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: Original Television Soundtrack - Series 4: The Specials (page does not exist)">fourth</a> was released on 4 October 2010 as a two disc special edition and contained music from the 2008–2010 specials (<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Next_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Next Doctor (page does not exist)">The Next Doctor</a></i> to <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_End_of_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The End of Time (page does not exist)">End of Time Part 2</a></i>).<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[113]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[114]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_Original_Television_Soundtrack_-_Series_5&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: Original Television Soundtrack - Series 5 (page does not exist)">soundtrack for Series 5</a> was released on 8 November 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[115]</a></sup> In February 2011, a soundtrack was released for the 2010 Christmas Special: "A Christmas Carol",<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[116]</a></sup> and in December 2011 the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_Original_Television_Soundtrack_-_Series_6&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: Original Television Soundtrack - Series 6 (page does not exist)">soundtrack for Series 6</a> was released, both by Silva Screen Records.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[117]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Viewership">Viewership</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="United_Kingdom">United Kingdom</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Dr_Who_(316350537).jpg" title="File:Dr Who (316350537).jpg">File:Dr Who (316350537).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The image of the <a href="/wiki/TARDIS" title="TARDIS">TARDIS</a> is iconic in British popular culture.</div></div></div>
<p>Premiering the day after the <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_F._Kennedy_assassination&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John F. Kennedy assassination (page does not exist)">John F. Kennedy assassination</a>, the first episode of <i>Doctor Who</i> was repeated with the second episode the following week. <i>Doctor Who</i> has always appeared initially on the BBC's mainstream BBC One channel, where it is regarded as a family show, drawing audiences of many millions of viewers; episodes are now repeated on <a href="/wiki/BBC_Three" title="BBC Three">BBC Three</a>. The programme's popularity has waxed and waned over the decades, with three notable periods of high ratings.<sup id="cite_ref-ratings_chart_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ratings_chart-124">[118]</a></sup> The first of these was the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Dalekmania&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dalekmania (page does not exist)">Dalekmania</a>" period (circa 1964–1965), when the popularity of the Daleks regularly brought <i>Doctor Who</i> ratings of between 9 and 14&#160;million, even for stories which did not feature them.<sup id="cite_ref-ratings_chart_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ratings_chart-124">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[119]</a></sup> The second was the late 1970s, when Tom Baker occasionally drew audiences of over 12&#160;million.<sup id="cite_ref-ratings_chart_124-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ratings_chart-124">[118]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/ITV_(TV_network)" title="ITV (TV network)">ITV</a> network strike of 1979, viewership peaked at 16&#160;million.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} Figures remained respectable into the 1980s, but fell noticeably after the programme's 23rd series was postponed in 1985 and the show was off the air for 18 months. Its late 1980s performance of three to five million viewers was seen as poor at the time and was, according to the BBC Board of Control, a leading cause of the programme's 1989 suspension. Some fans considered this disingenuous, since the programme was scheduled against the soap opera <i><a href="/wiki/Coronation_Street" title="Coronation Street">Coronation Street</a></i>, the most popular show at the time. After the series' revival in 2005 (the third notable period of high ratings), it has consistently had high viewership levels for the evening on which the episode is broadcast.<sup id="cite_ref-ratings_chart_124-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ratings_chart-124">[118]</a></sup> The BBC One broadcast of "<a href="/wiki/Rose_(Doctor_Who)" title="Rose (Doctor Who)">Rose</a>", the first episode of the 2005 revival, drew an average audience of 10.81&#160;million, third highest for BBC One that week and seventh across all channels.<sup id="cite_ref-ratings_chart_124-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ratings_chart-124">[118]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[120]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[121]</a></sup> The current revival also garners the highest audience <a href="/w/index.php?title=Appreciation_Index&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Appreciation Index (page does not exist)">Appreciation Index</a> of any drama on television.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="International">International</span></h3>
<p>Doctor Who has been broadcast internationally outside of the United Kingdom since 1964, a year after the show first aired. As of 1 January 2013, the modern series has been or is currently broadcast weekly in more than 50 countries.
</p><p><i>Doctor Who</i> is one of the five top grossing titles for <a href="/wiki/BBC_Worldwide" title="BBC Worldwide">BBC Worldwide</a>, the BBC's commercial arm.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[123]</a></sup> BBC Worldwide CEO <a href="/wiki/John_Smith_(BBC_executive)" title="John Smith (BBC executive)">John Smith</a> has said that <i>Doctor Who</i> is one of a small number of "Superbrands" which Worldwide will promote heavily.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Only four episodes have ever had their premiere showings on channels other than BBC One. The 1983 20th anniversary special <i><a href="/wiki/The_Five_Doctors" title="The Five Doctors">The Five Doctors</a></i> had its début on 23 November (the actual date of the anniversary) on a number of PBS stations two days prior to its BBC One broadcast. The 1988 story <i><a href="/wiki/Silver_Nemesis" title="Silver Nemesis">Silver Nemesis</a></i> was broadcast with all three episodes airing back to back on <a href="/wiki/Television_New_Zealand" title="Television New Zealand">TVNZ</a> in New Zealand in November, after the first episode had been shown in the UK but before the final two instalments had aired there. Finally, the 1996 television film premièred on 12 May 1996 on <a href="/w/index.php?title=CITV-TV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="CITV-TV (page does not exist)">CITV</a> in Edmonton, Canada, 15 days before the BBC One showing, and two days before it aired on <a href="/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company" title="Fox Broadcasting Company">Fox</a> in the United States.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Oceania">Oceania</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Zealand&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Zealand (page does not exist)">New Zealand</a> was the first country outside the United Kingdom to screen <i>Doctor Who</i>, beginning in September 1964, and continued to screen the series for many years, including the new series from 2005. In Canada, the series debuted in January 1965, but the CBC only aired the first 26 episodes. <a href="/wiki/TVOntario" title="TVOntario">TVOntario</a> picked up the show in 1976 beginning with <i><a href="/wiki/The_Three_Doctors_(Doctor_Who)" title="The Three Doctors (Doctor Who)">The Three Doctors</a></i> and aired each series (several years late) through to series 24 in 1991. From 1979 to 1981, TVO airings were bookended by science-fiction writer <a href="/wiki/Judith_Merril" title="Judith Merril">Judith Merril</a> who would introduce the episode and then, after the episode concluded, try to place it in an educational context in keeping with TVO's status as an educational channel. Its airing of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Talons_of_Weng-Chiang" title="The Talons of Weng-Chiang">The Talons of Weng-Chiang</a></i> was cancelled as a result of accusations that the story was <a href="/wiki/Racism" title="Racism">racist</a>; the story was later broadcast in the 1990s on cable station YTV. CBC began showing the series again in 2005. The series moved to the Canadian cable channel <a href="/wiki/Space_(TV_channel)" title="Space (TV channel)">Space</a> in 2009.
</p><p>In <a href="/w/index.php?title=Australia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Australia (page does not exist)">Australia</a>, the show has had a strong fan base since it's inception, having been exclusively first run by the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Broadcasting_Corporation" title="Australian Broadcasting Corporation">Australian Broadcasting Corporation</a> (ABC) since January 1965. The ABC has periodically repeated episodes; of note were the weekly screenings of all available classic episodes starting in 2003, for the show's 40th anniversary. The ABC broadcasts the modern series first run on <a href="/w/index.php?title=ABC1&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="ABC1 (page does not exist)">ABC1</a>, with repeats on <a href="/wiki/ABC2" title="ABC2">ABC2</a>. The ABC also provided partial funding for the 20th anniversary special <i>The Five Doctors</i> in 1983. Repeats of both the classic and modern series have also been shown on subscription television channels <a href="/wiki/BBC_UKTV" title="BBC UKTV">BBC UKTV</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=SF_Channel_(Australia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SF Channel (Australia) (page does not exist)">SF</a> and later on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Syfy_(Australia)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Syfy (Australia) (page does not exist)">SyFy</a> upon SF's closure.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="North_America">North America</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>The series also has a fan base in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>, where it was shown in <a href="/wiki/Broadcast_syndication" title="Broadcast syndication">syndication</a> from the 1970s to the 1990s, particularly on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Public_Broadcasting_Service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Public Broadcasting Service (page does not exist)">PBS</a> stations.
</p><p>For the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Canada&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Canada (page does not exist)">Canadian</a> broadcast, Christopher Eccleston recorded special video introductions for each episode (including a trivia question as part of a viewer contest) and excerpts from the <i>Doctor Who Confidential</i> documentary were played over the closing credits; for the broadcast of "<a href="/wiki/The_Christmas_Invasion" title="The Christmas Invasion">The Christmas Invasion</a>" on 26 December 2005, <a href="/wiki/Billie_Piper" title="Billie Piper">Billie Piper</a> recorded a special video introduction. CBC began airing series two on 9 October 2006 at 20:00 E/P (20:30 in Newfoundland and Labrador), shortly after that day's <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Football_League" title="Canadian Football League">CFL</a> double header on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thanksgiving_(Canada)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thanksgiving (Canada) (page does not exist)">Thanksgiving</a> in most of the country.
</p><p>Series three began broadcasting on BBC One in the United Kingdom on 31 March 2007. It began broadcasting on CBC on 18 June 2007 followed by the second Christmas special, "<a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Runaway_Bride_(Doctor_Who)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Runaway Bride (Doctor Who) (page does not exist)">The Runaway Bride</a>" at midnight,<sup id="cite_ref-RB_131-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RB-131">[125]</a></sup> and the Sci Fi Channel began on 6 July 2007 starting with the second Christmas special at 8:00&#160;pm E/P followed by the first episode.<sup id="cite_ref-S3_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-S3-132">[126]</a></sup>
</p><p>Series four aired in the United States on the Sci Fi Channel (now known as <a href="/wiki/Syfy" title="Syfy">Syfy</a>), beginning in April 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-S4USA_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-S4USA-133">[127]</a></sup> It aired on CBC beginning 19 September 2008, although the CBC did not air the <i>Voyage of the Damned</i> special.<sup id="cite_ref-s4Canada_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-s4Canada-134">[128]</a></sup> The Canadian cable network <a href="/wiki/Space_(TV_channel)" title="Space (TV channel)">Space</a> broadcast "The Next Doctor" (in March 2009) and all subsequent series and specials.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[129]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Other_countries">Other countries</span></h4>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Latin_America" title="Latin America">Latin America</a>, the original series&#160;— known as <i>Doctor Misterio</i>&#160;– was shown in Venezuela from 1967; Mexico (Canal 13) from 1968, then later syndicated from 1979; and Chile from 1969.
</p><p>A special logo has been designed for the <a href="/wiki/Japan" title="Japan">Japanese</a> broadcast with the <a href="/wiki/Katakana" title="Katakana">katakana</a> "ドクター・フー" (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Romanization_of_Japanese&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Romanization of Japanese (page does not exist)">romanised</a> as <i>Dokutā Fū</i>).<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[130]</a></sup> The series has apparently "mystified" viewers in Japan where it has been broadcast in a late evening time slot, leading to some not realising it is a family show.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[131]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="DVD_and_video">DVD and video</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
A wide selection of serials are available from BBC Video on DVD, on sale in the United Kingdom, Australia, Canada and the United States. Every fully extant serial has been released on VHS, and BBC Worldwide continues to regularly <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Doctor_Who_DVD_releases&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Doctor Who DVD releases (page does not exist)">release serials on DVD</a>. The 2005 series is also available in its entirety on <a href="/wiki/Universal_Media_Disc" title="Universal Media Disc">UMD</a> for the <a href="/wiki/PlayStation_Portable" title="PlayStation Portable">PlayStation Portable</a>. Eight original series serials have been released on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Laserdisc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Laserdisc (page does not exist)">Laserdisc</a><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[132]</a></sup> and many have also been released on <a href="/wiki/Betamax" title="Betamax">Betamaxtape</a> and <a href="/wiki/Video_2000" title="Video 2000">Video 2000</a>. One episode of Doctor Who <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Infinite_Quest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Infinite Quest (page does not exist)">The Infinite Quest</a> was released on <a href="/w/index.php?title=VCD&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="VCD (page does not exist)">VCD</a>. So far only the new series from 2009 onwards are available on <a href="/wiki/Blu-ray" title="Blu-ray" class="mw-redirect">Blu-ray</a>. The 1970 classic series story <i><a href="/wiki/Spearhead_from_Space" title="Spearhead from Space">Spearhead from Space</a></i> was released on Blu-ray in July 2013. Many early releases have been re-released on special edition with more bonus features.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Adaptations_and_other_appearances">Adaptations and other appearances</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Doctor_Who_films"><i>Doctor Who</i> films</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
There are two <i>Doctor Who</i> feature films: <i><a href="/wiki/Dr._Who_and_the_Daleks" title="Dr. Who and the Daleks">Dr. Who and the Daleks</a></i>, released in 1965 and <i><a href="/wiki/Daleks_%E2%80%93_Invasion_Earth:_2150_A.D." title="Daleks – Invasion Earth: 2150 A.D.">Daleks&#160;– Invasion Earth: 2150 A.D.</a></i> in 1966. Both are retellings of existing television stories (specifically, the first two Dalek serials, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daleks" title="The Daleks">The Daleks</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Dalek_Invasion_of_Earth" title="The Dalek Invasion of Earth">The Dalek Invasion of Earth</a></i> respectively) with a larger budget and alterations to the series concept.
</p><p>In these films, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Cushing" title="Peter Cushing">Peter Cushing</a> plays a human scientist<sup id="cite_ref-Tele1_139-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tele1-139">[133]</a></sup> named "Dr. Who", who travels with his granddaughter and niece and other companions in a time machine he has invented. The <a href="/wiki/Dr._Who_(Dalek_films)#Other_appearances" title="Dr. Who (Dalek films)">Cushing version</a> of the character reappears in both comic strips and a short story, the latter attempting to reconcile the film continuity with that of the series.
</p><p>In addition, several planned films were proposed, including a sequel, <i>The Chase</i>, loosely based on the <a href="/wiki/The_Chase_(Doctor_Who)" title="The Chase (Doctor Who)">original series story</a>, for the Cushing Doctor, plus <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_unmade_Doctor_Who_serials_and_films&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of unmade Doctor Who serials and films (page does not exist)">many attempted television movie and big screen productions</a> to revive the original <i>Doctor Who</i>, after the original series was cancelled.
</p><p>Paul McGann starred in <a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who_(film)" title="Doctor Who (film)">the only television film</a> as the eighth incarnation of the Doctor. After the film, he continued the role in audio books and was confirmed as the eighth incarnation through flashback footage and a mini episode in the 2005 revival, effectively linking the two series and the television movie.
</p><p>In 2011, <a href="/wiki/David_Yates" title="David Yates">David Yates</a> announced that he had started work with the BBC on a <i>Doctor Who</i> film, a project that would take three or more years to complete. Yates indicated that the film would take a different approach to <i>Doctor Who</i>,<sup id="cite_ref-VarietyWhoFilm_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-VarietyWhoFilm-140">[134]</a></sup> although the current <i>Doctor Who</i> showrunner <a href="/wiki/Steven_Moffat" title="Steven Moffat">Steven Moffat</a> stated later that any such film would not be a reboot of the series and a film should be made by the BBC team and star the current TV Doctor.<sup id="cite_ref-DigitalSpyWhoFilm_141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DigitalSpyWhoFilm-141">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spin-offs">Spin-offs</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<i>Doctor Who</i> has appeared on stage numerous times. In the early 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Trevor_Martin" title="Trevor Martin">Trevor Martin</a> played the role in <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_and_the_Daleks_in_the_Seven_Keys_to_Doomsday&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who and the Daleks in the Seven Keys to Doomsday (page does not exist)">Doctor Who and the Daleks in the Seven Keys to Doomsday</a></i>. In the late 1980s, Jon Pertwee and Colin Baker both played the Doctor at different times during the run of a play titled <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_%E2%80%93_The_Ultimate_Adventure&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who – The Ultimate Adventure (page does not exist)">Doctor Who&#160;– The Ultimate Adventure</a></i>. For two performances, while Pertwee was ill, <a href="/wiki/David_Banks_(actor)" title="David Banks (actor)">David Banks</a> (better known for playing <a href="/wiki/Cyberman" title="Cyberman">Cybermen</a>) played the Doctor. Other original plays have been staged as amateur productions, with other actors playing the Doctor, while <a href="/wiki/Terry_Nation" title="Terry Nation">Terry Nation</a> wrote <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Curse_of_the_Daleks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Curse of the Daleks (page does not exist)">The Curse of the Daleks</a></i>, a stage play mounted in the late 1960s, but without the Doctor.
</p><p>A pilot episode ("<a href="/w/index.php?title=A_Girl%27s_Best_Friend&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="A Girl's Best Friend (page does not exist)">A Girl's Best Friend</a>") for a potential spinoff series, <i><a href="/wiki/K-9_and_Company" title="K-9 and Company">K-9 and Company</a></i>, was aired in 1981 with <a href="/wiki/Elisabeth_Sladen" title="Elisabeth Sladen">Elisabeth Sladen</a> reprising her role as companion <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Jane_Smith" title="Sarah Jane Smith">Sarah Jane Smith</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Leeson" title="John Leeson">John Leeson</a> as the voice of <a href="/wiki/K-9_(Doctor_Who)" title="K-9 (Doctor Who)">K-9</a>, but was not picked up as a regular series.
</p><p>Concept art for an animated <i>Doctor Who</i> series was produced by animation company <a href="/wiki/Nelvana" title="Nelvana">Nelvana</a> in the 1980s, but the series was not produced.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[137]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following the success of the 2005 series produced by Russell T Davies, the BBC commissioned Davies to produce a 13-part spin-off series titled <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Torchwood&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Torchwood (page does not exist)">Torchwood</a></i> (an <a href="/wiki/Anagram" title="Anagram">anagram</a> of "Doctor Who"), set in modern-day <a href="/wiki/Cardiff" title="Cardiff">Cardiff</a> and investigating alien activities and crime. The series debuted on <a href="/wiki/BBC_Three" title="BBC Three">BBC Three</a> on 22 October 2006.<sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[138]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/John_Barrowman" title="John Barrowman">John Barrowman</a> reprised his role of <a href="/wiki/Jack_Harkness" title="Jack Harkness">Jack Harkness</a> from the 2005 series of <i>Doctor Who</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[139]</a></sup> Two other actresses who appeared in Doctor Who also star in the series; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Eve_Myles&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Eve Myles (page does not exist)">Eve Myles</a> as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gwen_Cooper&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gwen Cooper (page does not exist)">Gwen Cooper</a>, who also played the similarly named servant girl Gwyneth in the 2005 <i>Doctor Who</i> episode "<a href="/wiki/The_Unquiet_Dead" title="The Unquiet Dead">The Unquiet Dead</a>",<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[140]</a></sup> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Naoko_Mori&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Naoko Mori (page does not exist)">Naoko Mori</a> who reprised her role as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Toshiko_Sato&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Toshiko Sato (page does not exist)">Toshiko Sato</a> first seen in "<a href="/wiki/Aliens_of_London" title="Aliens of London">Aliens of London</a>". A second series of <i>Torchwood</i> aired in 2008; for three episodes, the cast was joined by Freema Agyeman reprising her <i>Doctor Who</i> role of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Martha_Jones&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Martha Jones (page does not exist)">Martha Jones</a>. A third series was broadcast from 6 to 10 July 2009, and consisted of a single five-part story called <i>Children of Earth</i> which was set largely in London. A fourth series, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Torchwood:_Miracle_Day&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Torchwood: Miracle Day (page does not exist)">Torchwood: Miracle Day</a> jointly produced by BBC Wales, BBC Worldwide and the American entertainment company Starz debuted in 2011. The series was predominantly set in the United States, though Wales remained part of the show's setting.
</p><p><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Sarah_Jane_Adventures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Sarah Jane Adventures (page does not exist)">The Sarah Jane Adventures</a></i>, starring <a href="/wiki/Elisabeth_Sladen" title="Elisabeth Sladen">Elisabeth Sladen</a> who reprised her role as investigative journalist <a href="/wiki/Sarah_Jane_Smith" title="Sarah Jane Smith">Sarah Jane Smith</a>, was developed by <a href="/wiki/CBBC" title="CBBC">CBBC</a>; a special aired on New Year's Day 2007 and a full series began on 24 September 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[141]</a></sup> A second series followed in 2008, notable for (as noted above) featuring the return of Brigadier Lethbridge-Stewart. A third in 2009 featured a crossover appearance from the main show by <a href="/wiki/David_Tennant" title="David Tennant">David Tennant</a> as the Tenth Doctor. In 2010, a further such appearance featured <a href="/w/index.php?title=Matt_Smith_(actor)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Matt Smith (actor) (page does not exist)">Matt Smith</a> as the Eleventh Doctor alongside former companion actress <a href="/wiki/Katy_Manning" title="Katy Manning">Katy Manning</a> reprising her role as <a href="/wiki/Jo_Grant" title="Jo Grant">Jo Grant</a>. A final, three-story fifth series was transmitted in autumn 2011&#160;– uncompleted due to the death of Elisabeth Sladen in early 2011.
</p><p>An animated serial, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Infinite_Quest&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Infinite Quest (page does not exist)">The Infinite Quest</a></i>, aired alongside the 2007 series of <i>Doctor Who</i> as part of the children's television series <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Totally_Doctor_Who&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Totally Doctor Who (page does not exist)">Totally Doctor Who</a></i>. The serial featured the voices of series regulars David Tennant and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Freema_Agyeman&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freema Agyeman (page does not exist)">Freema Agyeman</a> but is not considered part of the 2007 series.<sup id="cite_ref-cartoon_bbc_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cartoon_bbc-148">[142]</a></sup> A second animated serial, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dreamland_(Doctor_Who)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dreamland (Doctor Who) (page does not exist)">Dreamland</a></i>, aired in six parts on the <a href="/wiki/BBC_Red_Button" title="BBC Red Button">BBC Red Button</a> service, and the official <i>Doctor Who</i> website in 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[143]</a></sup>
</p><p>Numerous other spin-off series have been created not by the BBC but by the respective owners of the characters and concepts. Such spin-offs include the novel and audio drama series <i><a href="/wiki/Faction_Paradox" title="Faction Paradox">Faction Paradox</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Iris_Wildthyme" title="Iris Wildthyme">Iris Wildthyme</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Bernice_Summerfield" title="Bernice Summerfield">Bernice Summerfield</a></i>; as well as the made-for-video series <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=P.R.O.B.E.&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="P.R.O.B.E. (page does not exist)">P.R.O.B.E.</a></i>; the Australian-produced television series <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=K-9_(TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="K-9 (TV series) (page does not exist)">K-9</a></i>, which aired a 26-episode first season on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Disney_XD_(UK_%26_Ireland)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Disney XD (UK &amp; Ireland) (page does not exist)">Disney XD</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[144]</a></sup> and the audio spin-off <i>Counter-Measures</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[145]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Charity_episodes">Charity episodes</span></h3>
<p>In 1983, coinciding with the series' 20th anniversary, a charity special titled <i><a href="/wiki/The_Five_Doctors" title="The Five Doctors">The Five Doctors</a></i> was produced in aid of Children in Need, featuring three of the first five Doctors, a new actor to replace the deceased William Hartnell, and unused footage to represent Tom Baker.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[146]</a></sup> This was a full-length, 90-minute film, the longest single episode of <i>Doctor Who</i> produced to date (the television movie ran slightly longer on broadcast where it included commercial breaks).<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[148]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1993, for the franchise's 30th anniversary, another charity special, titled <i><a href="/wiki/Dimensions_in_Time" title="Dimensions in Time">Dimensions in Time</a></i> was produced for Children in Need, featuring all of the surviving actors who played the Doctor and a number of previous companions. It also featured a crossover with the soap opera <i><a href="/wiki/EastEnders" title="EastEnders">EastEnders</a></i>, the action taking place in the latter's <a href="/wiki/Albert_Square" title="Albert Square">Albert Square</a> location and around <a href="/wiki/Greenwich" title="Greenwich">Greenwich</a>. The special was one of several special 3D programmes the BBC produced at the time, using a 3D system that made use of the <a href="/wiki/Pulfrich_effect" title="Pulfrich effect">Pulfrich effect</a> requiring glasses with one darkened lens; the picture would look normal to those viewers who watched without the glasses.
</p><p>In 1999, another special, <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who_and_the_Curse_of_Fatal_Death" title="Doctor Who and the Curse of Fatal Death">Doctor Who and the Curse of Fatal Death</a></i>, was made for <a href="/wiki/Comic_Relief" title="Comic Relief">Comic Relief</a> and later released on VHS. An affectionate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Parody&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Parody (page does not exist)">parody</a> of the television series, it was split into four segments, mimicking the traditional serial format, complete with <a href="/wiki/Cliffhanger" title="Cliffhanger">cliffhangers</a>, and running down the same corridor several times when being chased (the version released on video was split into only two episodes). In the story, the Doctor (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Rowan_Atkinson&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rowan Atkinson (page does not exist)">Rowan Atkinson</a>) encounters both <a href="/wiki/Master_(Doctor_Who)" title="Master (Doctor Who)">the Master</a> (<a href="/wiki/Jonathan_Pryce" title="Jonathan Pryce">Jonathan Pryce</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Dalek" title="Dalek">Daleks</a>. During the special the Doctor is forced to regenerate several times, with his subsequent incarnations played by, in order, <a href="/wiki/Richard_E._Grant" title="Richard E. Grant">Richard E. Grant</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jim_Broadbent" title="Jim Broadbent">Jim Broadbent</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Grant" title="Hugh Grant">Hugh Grant</a> and <a href="/wiki/Joanna_Lumley" title="Joanna Lumley">Joanna Lumley</a>. The script was written by <a href="/wiki/Steven_Moffat" title="Steven Moffat">Steven Moffat</a>, later to be head writer and executive producer to the revived series.<sup id="cite_ref-RTDgone_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RTDgone-23">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>Since the return of <i>Doctor Who</i> in 2005, the franchise has produced two original "mini-episodes" to support Children in Need. The first, aired in November 2005, was an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who:_Children_in_Need&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who: Children in Need (page does not exist)">untitled seven-minute scene</a> which introduced <a href="/wiki/David_Tennant" title="David Tennant">David Tennant</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Tenth_Doctor" title="Tenth Doctor">Tenth Doctor</a>. It was followed in November 2007 by "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Crash&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Crash (page does not exist)">Time Crash</a>", a 7-minute scene which featured the Tenth Doctor meeting the <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Doctor" title="Fifth Doctor">Fifth Doctor</a> (played once again by <a href="/wiki/Peter_Davison" title="Peter Davison">Peter Davison</a>).
</p><p>A set of two mini-episodes, titled <a href="/w/index.php?title=Space_/_Time&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Space / Time (page does not exist)">"Space" and "Time"</a> respectively, were produced to support <a href="/wiki/Comic_Relief" title="Comic Relief">Comic Relief</a>. They were aired during the <a href="/wiki/Comic_Relief#2011_event" title="Comic Relief">Comic Relief 2011 event</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-comicrelief2011_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-comicrelief2011-155">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>During 2011 <a href="/wiki/Children_in_Need" title="Children in Need">Children in Need</a>, an exclusively-filmed segment showed the Doctor addressing the viewer, attempting to persuade them to purchase items of his clothing, which were going up for auction for Children in Need. The 2012 edition of CiN featured the mini-episode <i>The Great Detective</i>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Spoofs_and_cultural_references">Spoofs and cultural references</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<i>Doctor Who</i> has been satirised and spoofed on many occasions by comedians including <a href="/wiki/Spike_Milligan" title="Spike Milligan">Spike Milligan</a> (a Dalek invades his bathroom&#160;— Milligan, naked, hurls a soap sponge at it) and <a href="/wiki/Lenny_Henry" title="Lenny Henry">Lenny Henry</a>. <a href="/wiki/Jon_Culshaw" title="Jon Culshaw">Jon Culshaw</a> frequently impersonates the Fourth Doctor in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC (page does not exist)">BBC</a> <i><a href="/wiki/Dead_Ringers_(comedy)" title="Dead Ringers (comedy)">Dead Ringers</a></i> series.<sup id="cite_ref-Dead_Ringers_meets_Doctor_Who_156-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dead_Ringers_meets_Doctor_Who-156">[150]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_fandom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who fandom (page does not exist)"><i>Doctor Who</i> fandom</a> has also been lampooned on programs such as <i><a href="/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live" title="Saturday Night Live">Saturday Night Live</a></i>, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Chaser%27s_War_on_Everything&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Chaser's War on Everything (page does not exist)">The Chaser's War on Everything</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Mystery_Science_Theater_3000" title="Mystery Science Theater 3000">Mystery Science Theater 3000</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Family_Guy" title="Family Guy">Family Guy</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/American_Dad!" title="American Dad!">American Dad!</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Futurama" title="Futurama">Futurama</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/South_Park" title="South Park">South Park</a></i>,
<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Community_(TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Community (TV series) (page does not exist)">Community</a></i> as Inspector Spacetime, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Simpsons" title="The Simpsons">The Simpsons</a></i> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Big_Bang_Theory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Big Bang Theory (page does not exist)">The Big Bang Theory</a></i>.
</p><p>The Doctor in his fourth incarnation has been represented on several episodes of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Simpsons" title="The Simpsons">The Simpsons</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-Fourth_Doctor_The_Simpsons_157-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fourth_Doctor_The_Simpsons-157">[151]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Matt_Groening" title="Matt Groening">Matt Groening</a>'s other animated series <i><a href="/wiki/Futurama" title="Futurama">Futurama</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Fourth_Doctor_Futurama_158-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fourth_Doctor_Futurama-158">[152]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Fourth_Doctor_Futurama_2_159-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Fourth_Doctor_Futurama_2-159">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>There have also been many references to <i>Doctor Who</i> in popular culture and other science fiction, including <i><a href="/wiki/Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation" title="Star Trek: The Next Generation">Star Trek: The Next Generation</a></i> ("<a href="/wiki/The_Neutral_Zone_(Star_Trek:_The_Next_Generation)" title="The Neutral Zone (Star Trek: The Next Generation)">The Neutral Zone</a>")<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[154]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Leverage_(TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Leverage (TV series) (page does not exist)">Leverage</a></i>. In the <a href="/wiki/Channel_4" title="Channel 4">Channel 4</a> series <i><a href="/wiki/Queer_as_Folk_(UK_TV_series)" title="Queer as Folk (UK TV series)">Queer As Folk</a></i> (created by later <i>Doctor Who</i> executive producer Russell T Davies), the character of Vince was portrayed as an avid <i>Doctor Who</i> fan, with references appearing many times throughout in the form of clips from the programme. In a similar manner, the character of Oliver on <i><a href="/wiki/Coupling" title="Coupling">Coupling</a></i> (created and written by current show runner <a href="/wiki/Steven_Moffat" title="Steven Moffat">Steven Moffat</a>) is portrayed as a <i>Doctor Who</i> collector and enthusiast.
References to <i>Doctor Who</i> have also appeared in the young adult fantasy novels <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Brisingr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Brisingr (page does not exist)">Brisingr</a></i><sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[155]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=High_Wizardry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="High Wizardry (page does not exist)">High Wizardry</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[156]</a></sup> the video game <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Rock_Band_(video_game)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rock Band (video game) (page does not exist)">Rock Band</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[157]</a></sup> the soap opera <i><a href="/wiki/EastEnders" title="EastEnders">EastEnders</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[158]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Adult_Swim" title="Adult Swim">Adult Swim</a> comedy show <i><a href="/wiki/Robot_Chicken" title="Robot Chicken">Robot Chicken</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Family_Guy" title="Family Guy">Family Guy</a></i> episodes "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Blue_Harvest_(Family_Guy)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Blue Harvest (Family Guy) (page does not exist)">Blue Harvest</a>" and "<a href="/w/index.php?title=420_(Family_Guy)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="420 (Family Guy) (page does not exist)">420</a>", and the game <a href="/wiki/RuneScape" title="RuneScape">RuneScape</a>.
</p><p><i>Doctor Who</i> has been a reference in several political cartoons, from a 1964 cartoon in the <i><a href="/wiki/Daily_Mail" title="Daily Mail">Daily Mail</a></i> depicting <a href="/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle" title="Charles de Gaulle">Charles de Gaulle</a> as a Dalek<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[159]</a></sup> to a 2008 edition of <i><a href="/wiki/This_Modern_World" title="This Modern World">This Modern World</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Tom_Tomorrow" title="Tom Tomorrow">Tom Tomorrow</a> in which the Tenth Doctor informs an incredulous character from 2003 that the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> will nominate <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">an African-American</a> as its presidential candidate.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[160]</a></sup>
</p><p>The word "TARDIS" is an entry in the <a href="/wiki/Shorter_Oxford_English_Dictionary" title="Shorter Oxford English Dictionary">Shorter Oxford English Dictionary</a><sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[161]</a></sup> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=IOS&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IOS (page does not exist)">iOS</a> dictionary.
</p><p>As part of the 50th anniversary programmes, former <a href="/wiki/Fifth_Doctor" title="Fifth Doctor">Fifth Doctor</a> Peter Davison created, wrote and co-starred in a parody <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Five(ish)_Doctors_Reboot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Five(ish) Doctors Reboot (page does not exist)">The Five(ish) Doctors Reboot</a></i> featuring cameos from several other formers Doctors, companions and people involved in the programme.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Museums_and_exhibitions">Museums and exhibitions</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>There have been various exhibitions of <i>Doctor Who</i> in the United Kingdom, including the now closed exhibitions at:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Lands_End" title="Lands End" class="mw-redirect">Lands End</a> (<a href="/wiki/Cornwall" title="Cornwall">Cornwall</a>)
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Blackpool" title="Blackpool">Blackpool</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Llangollen" title="Llangollen">Llangollen</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Kelvingrove_Art_Gallery_and_Museum" title="Kelvingrove Art Gallery and Museum">Kelvingrove Museum</a>, Glasgow
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Coventry_Transport_Museum" title="Coventry Transport Museum">Coventry Transport Museum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coventry" title="Coventry">Coventry</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Centre_for_life&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Centre for life (page does not exist)">Centre for life</a>, <a href="/wiki/Newcastle_upon_Tyne" title="Newcastle upon Tyne">Newcastle upon Tyne</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Melbourne&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Melbourne (page does not exist)">Melbourne</a>, Australia (only international DW concert to be performed)
</li>
<li> Kensington Olympia Two, London
</li>
</ul>
<p>There is an exhibition open currently in Cardiff (the city where the series is filmed)<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[163]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Merchandise">Merchandise</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Since its beginnings, <i>Doctor Who</i> has generated hundreds of products related to the show, from toys and games to collectible picture cards and postage stamps. These include board games, card games, gamebooks, computer games, roleplaying games, action figures and a pinball game. Many games have been released that feature the Daleks, including <a href="/wiki/Dalek#Computer_games" title="Dalek">Dalek computer games</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Audios">Audios</span></h3>
<p>The Doctor has also appeared in webcasts and in audio plays; among the latter were those produced by <a href="/wiki/Big_Finish_Productions" title="Big Finish Productions">Big Finish Productions</a>, who were responsible for a <a href="/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_audio_plays_by_Big_Finish" title="List of Doctor Who audio plays by Big Finish">range of audio plays</a> released on CD, as well as 2006's eight-part <a href="/w/index.php?title=BBC_7&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BBC 7 (page does not exist)">BBC 7</a> series starring <a href="/wiki/Paul_McGann" title="Paul McGann">Paul McGann</a>. Big Finish's productions began with the release of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Sirens_of_Time" title="The Sirens of Time">The Sirens of Time</a></i> in July 1999. These audios feature Doctors 4–8. As well as this, Big Finish also release a range of other audio books read by both Doctors and Companions.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Books">Books</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p><i>Doctor Who</i> books have been published from the mid-sixties through to the present day. From 1965 to 1991 the books published were primarily novelised adaptations of broadcast episodes; beginning in 1991 an extensive line of original fiction was launched, the <a href="/wiki/Virgin_New_Adventures" title="Virgin New Adventures">Virgin New Adventures</a> and <a href="/wiki/Virgin_Missing_Adventures" title="Virgin Missing Adventures">Virgin Missing Adventures</a>. Since the relaunch of the programme in 2005, a new range of novels have been published by <a href="/wiki/BBC_Books" title="BBC Books">BBC Books</a>. Numerous non-fiction books about the series, including guidebooks and critical studies, have also been published, and a dedicated <i><a href="/wiki/Doctor_Who_Magazine" title="Doctor Who Magazine">Doctor Who Magazine</a></i> with newsstand circulation has been published regularly since 1979. There is also a <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Doctor_Who_Adventures&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Doctor Who Adventures (page does not exist)">Doctor Who Adventures</a></i> magazine published by the BBC.
</p><p>See also:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Doctor_Who_novelisations&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Doctor Who novelisations (page does not exist)">List of Doctor Who novelisations</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Eighth_Doctor_Adventures" title="Eighth Doctor Adventures">Eighth Doctor Adventures</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Past_Doctor_Adventures" title="Past Doctor Adventures">Past Doctor Adventures</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Series_Adventures_(Doctor_Who)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Series Adventures (Doctor Who) (page does not exist)">New Series Adventures</a>
</li>
</ul>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Awards">Awards</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>In 1975, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Doctor_Who_serials#Season_11_.281973.E2.80.9374.29" title="List of Doctor Who serials">Season 11</a> of the series won a Writers' Guild of Great Britain award for Best Writing in a Children's Serial. In 1996, BBC television held the "Auntie Awards" as the culmination of their "TV60" series, celebrating 60 years of BBC television broadcasting, where <i>Doctor Who</i> was voted as the "Best Popular Drama" the corporation had ever produced, ahead of such ratings heavyweights as <i><a href="/wiki/EastEnders" title="EastEnders">EastEnders</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Casualty_(TV_series)" title="Casualty (TV series)">Casualty</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-auntieawards_170-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auntieawards-170">[164]</a></sup> In 2000, <i>Doctor Who</i> was ranked third in a list of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=100_Greatest_British_Television_Programmes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="100 Greatest British Television Programmes (page does not exist)">100 Greatest British Television Programmes</a> of the 20th century, produced by the <a href="/wiki/British_Film_Institute" title="British Film Institute">British Film Institute</a> and voted on by industry professionals.<sup id="cite_ref-tv100_171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tv100-171">[165]</a></sup> In 2005, the series came first in a survey by <a href="/w/index.php?title=SFX_magazine&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="SFX magazine (page does not exist)">SFX magazine</a> of "The Greatest UK Science Fiction and Fantasy Television Series Ever". Also, in the 100 Greatest Kids' TV shows (a <a href="/wiki/Channel_4" title="Channel 4">Channel 4</a> countdown in 2001), the 1963–1989 run was placed at number eight.
</p><p>The revived series has received recognition from critics and the public, across various awards ceremonies. It won five <a href="/w/index.php?title=BAFTA_TV_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BAFTA TV Award (page does not exist)">BAFTA TV Awards</a>, including <a href="/w/index.php?title=British_Academy_Television_Award_for_Best_Drama_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="British Academy Television Award for Best Drama Series (page does not exist)">Best Drama Series</a>, the highest-profile and most prestigious British television award for which the series has ever been nominated.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[166]</a></sup> It was very popular at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=BAFTA_Cymru&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BAFTA Cymru (page does not exist)">BAFTA Cymru Awards</a>, with 25 wins overall including Best Drama Series (twice), Best Screenplay/Screenwriter (thrice) and Best Actor.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[167]</a></sup> It was also nominated for 7 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saturn_Award&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saturn Award (page does not exist)">Saturn Awards</a>, winning the only <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saturn_Award_for_Best_International_Series&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saturn Award for Best International Series (page does not exist)">Best International Series</a> in the ceremony's history. In 2009, <i>Doctor Who</i> was voted the 3rd greatest show of the 2000s by Channel 4, behind <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Top_Gear_(2002_TV_series)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Top Gear (2002 TV series) (page does not exist)">Top Gear</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Apprentice_(UK_TV_series)" title="The Apprentice (UK TV series)">The Apprentice</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Top_Gear_takes_decade.27s_top_show_accolade_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Top_Gear_takes_decade.27s_top_show_accolade-174">[168]</a></sup> The episode "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Vincent_and_the_Doctor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vincent and the Doctor (page does not exist)">Vincent and the Doctor</a>" was <a href="/w/index.php?title=Short_list&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Short list (page does not exist)">shortlisted</a> for a Mind Award at the 2010 Mind Mental Health Media Awards for its "touching" portrayal of <a href="/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh" title="Vincent van Gogh">Vincent van Gogh</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>It has won every year since 2006 (except in 2009) the Short Form of the <a href="/wiki/Hugo_Award_for_Best_Dramatic_Presentation,_Short_Form" title="Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation, Short Form" class="mw-redirect">Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation</a>, the oldest science fiction/fantasy award for films and series.
